review_title: IBM Canada is a great and challenging place to work
job_title: Client Solutions Executive in Toronto, ON
pros: IBM has a flexible work policy that typically allows you to work from home. It's a dynamic global organization where you get to interact the best people in their field. You can see the breadth of the IT space from Industry consulting to Software, Hardware and outsourcing.
cons: IBM is flexible about where you work but expect to work a lot of hours. IBM is also as others have said a big ship. If you accept you can nudge the ship in on direction or another and given enough time and the right circumstance maybe 45 degrees. Don't expect to be able to corner on a dime or turn it around.

review_title: Extremely limited mobility and salary potential...
job_title: Level II Support in San Jose, CA
pros: There are a lot of nice people to work with and opportunities to learn and take leadership/responsibility. Relatively good job security unless you are in the hardware / storage side of the business..
cons:
Even with multiple years in a row of '1' PBC performances, salary raises are incredibly limited. Typically 1-2% a year would be 'great' year. This is coming from someone who put in 50-60 hours a week. Teams and entire groups make it extremely difficult to move laterally within the company because they have such a hard time back filling positions (getting open reqs).

Get used to having a used (old) laptop and then having to hold on to it for 4 years before an upgrade. Basically "BYOD" is mandatory if you care about your equipment. The security / process is ridiculous.. easily spend 20% of your time just doing that stuff.

There are too many people who were acquired and have great salaries.. there is just no incentive for them to work hard. For example, in the same job role, there could be one guy making $150k, and another making $75k for the same job. The guy at $150k has no incentive to work hard because they are capped at their band level and are unlikely to make more money. The other guy at $75k also has no incentive to work hard because even if they are an all-star, they will get maybe a 1% raise if they are lucky.

I can't even count the number of people that work remote that just stay in "meeting mode" all day. You know perfectly well they are just making themselves look busy.. ridiculous. Get them back into the office and productivity would likely crease 2x.

review_title: Great balance and freedom.
job_title: Research Staff Member in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros: Great work-life balance.  Lots of working from home -- which is especially helpful for new parents or folks dealing with sick loved-ones.  IBM shows a lot of trust in its researchers to choose their own problems and drive them.  It also encourages collaboration with academia and it's a good way to get interns to come and work for you while staying on the cutting edge and relevant in the broader research community.
cons: Lots of older IBMers don't get the way the world works today, and that's alarming.  The notion that everything open source is winning and everyone wants everything "as a service" is a fairly new concept that hasn't entirely been accepted by all within research.  With the research organization being so large there are people who just don't get how to do impactful research anymore.  They're so focused on supporting the current busniess that they spend years without any significant publications and lose sight of what are the important problems that will prepare IBM to compete.  There's almost a unethical drive to get more patents -- even for stuff we'll never build.  In effect, IBM Research is the biggest patent troll there is.  Also, the bonuses are *tiny* (around 1% for average performance and <10% for the best of the best performers).  I don't know what it used to be like at IBM Research but it's obvious why the best people arrive, love the freedom, and then realize top-notch research will not be rewarded unless it makes it into products within a year.  To make up for longer-term results, you have to write patents, since at least that does generate revenue for the division.

review_title: Great place to work , process oriented company, below average hikes, powerless HR
pros:
- Fantastic work life balance: work from home, unlimited sick leave facility, great policies for women
- Good policies overall - shift/standby allowances, mobile, data card, fuel reimbursement if working in support projects
- Extremely process oriented company - once you get to understand the processes, its smooth sailing. 
- Ocean of knowledge - if you are here to learn and for experience, there's infinite possibilities. Wealth of trainings and experience can be gained. The top consultants in virtually any field are just a click away. 
- Contacts / Networking is everything - this is a pro as well as a Con. If you have the right network, you can get virtually any kind of assignment you want
- If you know how to crack the processes, you can get the band progressions regularly. Pay attention to the process based trainings. they are more important than you realize.
- Its a laid back company. If a person wants, he can relax and have a chilled out life here. On the flip side, if you want to work, you will get terrific opportunities. 
Have patience, and follow the process. You will get what you want.
cons:
- Below average salary hikes. top rating for continuous 5 years, and total pay rise since joining is <50%. Average <10% hike per year. 
- Variable pay is a joke. Its dependant on company performance and can range from 10-50% of what is promised (GDP). Performance bonus (for 1 rating) is usually a decent amount. 
- HR is powerless. Everything , from leaves, hikes, promotions, appraisals, WFH approvals is in people manager's hands. If you have a good PeM, your life is set. If he turns out to be "evil", it can be pretty bad. 
- Contacts / Networking is everything - this is a pro as well as a Con. If you have do not habe the right contacts, you will be shuttled around to random projects by the resource managers. Zero bench policy ensures that they will tag you in virtually any account that will take you in. So BUILD YOUR NETWORK
- If you do not understand the internal processes, you will be lost. Promotions, hikes, appraisals, approvals - everything has a process to it. Have patience, and follow the process. You will get what you want.

review_title: Teaming culture with integrity
job_title: Account Executive in Los Angeles, CA
pros: IBM has a culture of collaboration, integrity, and performance.  Individuals are given contribution targets and are expected to achieve them, but working with others is a prerequisite for success.  The company often manages by matrix, meaning that you can have objectives from different managers with different objectives; e.g., manage costs and grow revenue.  This tension makes for better overall performance, in my opinion.  I have worked at firms that belittle their clients when they're off-site and IBM doesn't tend to be that way.
cons: You can get lost in the matrix if your manager isn't covering for you.  It's a big company and you need to have some political savvy as well as the ability to "cold call" within the organization to find the help you require.

review_title: When I joined the company 30 years ago, its tenet was "IBM's most valuable asset is its employees". How times change...

pros:

If you do land in one of the better projects you have many options
For experienced hires it seems fine, the issue is more with the graduate program
cons:
Experience varies strongly from graduate to graduate depending on task manager and project
Training does not seem very structured for practical knowledge, only soft skills have a decent training structure

review_title: Very Selfish Company
pros: Can't really think of any pros.
cons: Once you become an employee of IBM don't expect being treated as a human being, it is all about what the company wants. Fringe benefits are a thing of the past. Raises are nonexistent, unless you are in management. They get incentives for squeezing all they can out of workers. The "bean counters" are on their  jobs 24/7. Moral is at an all time low for employees who have helped place this company were it is today and when you think you have given all you can give, you find out that your job has been outsourced. So much for gratitude.

review_title: Great colleagues, very smart people, great big-picture technologies but management is only focused on the bottom line
pros: Work at home flexibility, autonomy depending on your manager, pays well, great benefits; some big-picture projects.
cons: Work overload, ongoing fear of layoffs, some of the processes are very rigid, extreme cost cutting that made team meetings impossible.  I never met my manager in the two years I worked for him due to cost reasons and we hadn't had a team meeting in 8 years for cost reasons.  Also while great, the work at home made some of us call IBM "I'm By Myself"

review_title: Not the company it used to be
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Large company with some sense of security if you are among the top contributors.  Benefits aren't bad.  Lots of room to move around if  you are  young and mobile.  Ability to work at home.
cons: Resource Actions instead of revenue growth.  Benefits degraded from what they used to be.  One of the values that attracted me to this company was "Respect for the Individual", that is LONG GONE and has been replaced by new values centered solely around business results.  Pensions are gone for new employees and been replaced by an adequate 401K.

review_title: Yikes
pros: A lot of opportunity within the company.  Allowing you to move around over the years.
cons: Terrible communication and culture fueled my Sr. Management.  Weekly focus on numbers causes a crazy number of sales cadence calls.  A toxic attitude has become pervasive after years of lay offs with little to no communication.  EPS goals for wall street are hurting moral and customer satisfaction.

review_title: Worst technology company I have worked for in my 25 year career
job_title: Technical Solution Specialist in London, England
pros:
Large company with a lot of career avenues to go down if you don't mind the cons (see below).
High amount of 'Life' in the 'work/life' balance (because of the cons .. see below).
cons:
Highly bureaucratic company where staff are measured on their conformance to internal procedures and not measured on their ability (at least in software group sales).
Poor pay with limited ability to gain annual raises that meet salaries of smaller technology companies. 
80% of employees focus is driven to be internal and not external on their customers where it should be. 
Very low innovation compared with the movers-and-shakers in the technology world right now.
Very difficult to actually get anything done with any speed due to the bureaucratic culture.

review_title: A huge ship slowly sinking
pros: Working from home full-time, work is easy, not stressful. Paid well relative to work and how much experience I have. Very rarely had to work over 40 hours per week and when I did, was paid overtime.  Learn what you can and get out!
cons: I was a contractor so no benefits.  Also no raises, training, promotions, etc.  Basically I was only there to do my job and fully disposable.  The company is like a huge cruise ship that is sinking. Employees rarely get raises and when they do it is peanuts.

review_title: IBM
pros: .Pays well, benefits, vacation, 401K
cons: Good pay but believe me you REALLY earn every dime. Highly competitive and large demands placed on every employee are extremely high. Therefore, you can't trust anyone you work with. Management isn't as well aware as they would have you think. Had 7 managers in 10 years. Some of them didn't have a clue about proper management. More concerned about meeting work objectives than managing people and helping them achieve their goals, opportunities or promotions..

review_title: Big corporate and all that goes with it
pros: Was a great company at a department level - intelligent people who got stuff done, and a product we could be proud of.  Real sense of teamwork.
cons: Doesn't invest in its people.  Several big releases in a row, leading to tired employees.  The reward for doing good work was more work.  The training budget was cut, but that didn't matter any more, because at that point there wasn't any time to train anyway.  Technical debt built up, and we didn't have enough people to address it.

review_title: Good Work Life Balance
job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: IBM offered flexible work hours.  The hours were long and there were no boundaries (i.e. 6a or 11p meetings on the same day are the norm); however, generally I could carve out time in the day to be there for my family.   The work at home environment allowed me to have more flexibility if a chlid was home sick.
cons: No growth potential in the US.   A strong focus on outsourcing minimized opportunity for growth within the US.

review_title: Don't join IBM India, and don't trust TechstoSuit Agency
pros:
Techs to Suit processed my profile to IBM and i have cleared all the interviews/Manager(PDM) rounds. Post interview process i got email form HR to submit all the necessary documents to process the offer letter but it's been three months i haven't received offer letter.

Techs To Suit Agency says:
-They don't have any clarity why IBM is not rolling out the offer letter, though they are able to see all the necessary approval everything in place.
-Lack of communication and transparency, they are just asking candidates to wait for some more days/months to get offer
-Don't understand what kind of hiring process between IBM and TechsToSuit....but they are spoiling candidates career by asking them to wait for 3-4 months and after that they will not respond any email/calls:(
cons: nothing...IBM company is cheating candidates by using it's Agencies/consultancies network.

review_title: Software engineer
pros: A lot of smart people and a lot of support from colleagues. Great benefits. Flexible hours and locations as long as you can deliver your work on time.
cons: Your career growth highly depends on you manager. Your SAM(service area manager) plays a huge role for your promotions. Sometimes it's unreasonable and totally unfair. I saw people did not do any much works, just because he/she worked in the same project as his/her SAM and he /she got promoted rapidly. A lot of good and smart people have left the company for that reason.

review_title: Good company, lots of red tape
pros: Easy access to decision-makers, excellent training, good products with strong R&D back-up . . . in other words, everything that a salesperson needs to compete.
cons: I have worked for several software companies over the years and my sense is that IBM pays less than the industry average.  As you might expect, big company = big bureaucracy and I never felt that I had the power to really deliver for my customers in the way that I would have liked.

review_title: Team Leader
pros: You can meet some great people. Its a good starting point for your career, because You can get a lots of basic experience. There is a wide range of different positions, so You can find position that suits You best. Great Work/Life balance.
cons: Corporate strategy doesn't seem to be heading the right way. Bureaucracy is ruling everything. Possibilities of personal development are limited. In the end its just about fire-fighting and there is no concept at all.

review_title: Average
pros: IBM Human Resources did it right. From the basic premise of a need to change, to using agile methods for design and feedback, to rolling it all out. They really are walking the talk when it comes to how best to provide feedback in a fast-moving, social environment. While the outside debate rages on about the value of performance management systems, IBM has done something about it, and has spent time listening to empl…
cons: We'll wait to see how well managers can incorporate this. Any performance review and coaching system is only as good as the managers who implement it. But the basics are all there for them to use.

review_title: Undergoing major transformation
job_title: Executive Briefing Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: The people and relationships I built in the company were and still are amazing.  With such a large corporation there are countless possibilities and with the right maneuvering it's possible to have a diverse and long career.  The company is currently in process of redefining itself which could mean great things for the future.
cons: The Core Values of the company are top notch, however, not often implemented or experienced by the everyday employee.  Raises, growth driven profit and numerous other perks have been dwindling for years.

review_title: A large organisation with quite a bit of beuracracy
job_title: Senior Data Scientist in London, England
pros:
Good pay
Good learning opportunities
Good brand
Good people
Quite accommodating to your needs
cons:
No free coffee..first organization I have worked for where nothing is free..not even hot water...
Expensive cafeteria....

Can get quite bureaucratic so if you are not used to a work culture and know how to get things done, it can become frustrating.

Growing within the organization  may be a challenge unless you are spending 30% of your time with that mindset to network, find opportunities and grow. Many IBMers actually move elsewhere to come back at a higher level

review_title: After a year and a half...
job_title: Remote Support Technician in Sofia, Sofia (city)
pros:
Opportunities for learning,
Can meet new people,
Working with some cutting edge tech,
Time flexibility and work from home is possible
cons:
Nepotism and weak, self-interested management
Low salary for this sector and type of job
Internal mechanisms of IBM are very old and clunky
Position advancement is based almost solely on seniority

review_title: Senior Sales Representative
pros: Flexible work and vacation schedules
cons: Lack of leadership from the Top down.  Very low employee morale in multiple divisions within the company. There is no trust between the employee population and management at the 1st, 2nd and 3rd levels.

review_title: Professionel and Challenging
job_title: C O O in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros: A company that impact lives and the world we are living in.  Very professional colleagues, that are willing to go the extra mile. Wealth of knowledge, insights and assets. Fun, demanding, rewarding - you are able to do a real difference.  Fantastic Corporate Responsibility and Corporate Citizenship profile that you as an employee easily can engage in. Work/Life balance absolutely possible but also require something of you.
cons: Difficult to navigate, your network is everything, you need patience and willingness to 'find the way', you need to be self motivated and self guided and willing to pursue what is right for you, your customer and the company despite roadblocks experienced. Bureaucratic and US Centric

review_title: Senior Security Delivery Specialist
job_title: Senior Security Delivery Specialist in Bangalore
pros:
One of the best in the industry. 
Best work life balance 
Amazing learning opportunities, well managed, employee friendly and good work environment
Great place to achieve and innovate new things. 
Many good things.. you will experience once you become an ibmer.
cons:
Poor pay scale

Though improving on appreciation side of employees.. needs a lot of focus on retaining good talents.

review_title: IBM works on Trust and Personal responisibilties in all relationship
pros: IBM gives freedom to work. It maintain diversity and integrity of its resources.
cons: As per my last 5 yrs stint at IBM, I felt it is a management -oriented organization. There are a lot of Red Tapism at higher management level. It is more client centric and not thinking in terms of resources welfare and their perspective. Human Resource has least value in IBM and weakest and literally a lame duck.

review_title: Not your father's IBM
job_title: Global Program Manager in Austin, TX
pros: I had heard glowing statements from recent new hires at IBM when I starting to look for a new career role.  Now that I've had 80 days as an IBM employee, I can state that the current IBM is a revitalized, open, collaborative, and exiting place to work.  The new collaborative mindset has been exciting yet surprising based on my prior experience at IBM.
cons: Some old systems still remain.  Most notably Lotus Notes.  Does any one outside of IBM use it any more?

review_title: Disappointed and unmotivated after 2 years as IBMer
job_title: IT Project Manager in Munich, Bavaria
pros:
As a young professional you get very quickly responsibility and growth potential. 

Depending on the project your are working in innovative and fast paced environments.
cons:
My advise —> dodge this bullet.

Employees are stucked in the same salary level for years...a lot of formal obstacles before you get a promotion.

You need a good network to get interesting project assignments.

Employees are treated like cost or productive factors. KPI and financially driven only.

Individuals preferences (e.g willingness to travel, preferred work location, etc)  are 2nd —> “you must obey and be billable.”

IBM follows a strong cuts plan for years, this leads to absurd decisions from management.

Management praises  unique and “new” company’s culture...but these values are not followed in reality

Huge old dinosaur with old legacy processes and hierarchy.

Unstable work environment...everyone can get fired next.

In my Departement the good and motivated co workers gave notice in last months.

review_title: It's worse than you've heard and not getting better
pros: Some powerful products to sell, huge global reach, smart people
cons: Management is constantly changing directions, people policies that show how little the company cares about it's employees, policies dictated from corporate that make little sense in some business units, ridiculous amounts of paperwork and corporate bureaucracy that make getting deals done near impossible (e.g. 24 approvals to release a simple price quote).  Salespeople required to sell the hot product of the day which is constantly changing and more often than not is vapor - go sell it and then we'll figure out how to deliver it (which NEVER works).  Constantly changing sales targets and territories - continuous reorganizations make it impossible to get traction in any one area.

review_title: great company
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in New York, NY
pros: company treats it employees well
cons: lots of employees and employees  are not visable

review_title: Great place to work

review_title: Working at IBM REALLY Sucks!
job_title: SAP Technical Consultant in Atlanta, GA
pros: A great place if you want to telecommute, their virtual services are second to none.
cons: Management is just plain incompetent at all levels.  You'll never get a decent raise.  They expect you to work 80 hour weeks in most cases. You'll get no respect from any level of management and in many cases clients are so fed up with IBM that they are just waiting for their SLAs to expire and then they go with someone else.  I've seen it happen over 8 times in the last 5 years.  It is absolutely appalling.

review_title: IBM is not a people company unless you live in India
job_title: Business Operations Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Flexibility.  You can work from home and live anywhere.
cons: A HUGE percentage of the jobs are being oursourced to other countries.  There is little funding for employee education.  This is not a people company anymore.  They just want you to work overtime all the time.  There is constantly this unspoken message that you better be happy that you have a job because we can outsource your job any day now.

review_title: Good company if you are not an American
pros: big company, diversified, generally decent benefits and hr policies.
cons: if you are a US citizen, it's unlikely you will have your job for long.  IBM is seemingly on the warpath to get rid of all American employees.  In some divisions, at least 65% of the employees are "global resource" .. apparently americans are not part of the 'global' community .. and that is only expected to go up.    Depending on your division, can be surprisingly cheap ... no money for education, travel etc., but other divisions can be quite generous, just luck of the draw where you end up.

review_title: Huge corporate monolith, too much politics and too many mini-empires...
pros: Work life balance.  Meet interesting diverse people, on the phone :-)  People you work with directly are all great..
cons: IBM invented Bullmerde bingo.  High Performance culture rewards top 10% year after year to the detriment of everyone else - who actually do the real work - instead of spending majority of the time telling everyone how wonderful they are...  Company takes advantage of their employees with expectation of working extra hours that are not compensated with overtime payments.

review_title: Big place but it takes care of its people
job_title: Manager, Marketing (Leads Team of People) in Armonk, NY
pros: The benefits.  In the US they appear to be fairly complete and seem to exceed those offered elsewhere.  There is also a great deal of flexibility in the physical work location that individuals can work from.  I have an employee who works for me in Asia Pacific, several in RTP, others in Florida, Massachusetts and Ohio.  This is a key benefit.
cons:
Because of the benefits, the cash compensation tends to lag behind some of its competitors.

One of the downsides to the flexibility and the remote teams is that it can take longer to develop the type of comradeship that teams who work face-to-face have.

review_title: low risk, low return
job_title: Delivery Project Executive in Fairfax, VA
pros:
1> Stable organization, decent benefits, great work-from-home culture.
2> Lots of groups, departments... If you don't fit somewhere, you can try your luck at another dept.
3> People are respectful of other people's viewpoints
cons:
1> No salary hike, no promotions
2> Not enough big projects in App Dev and Maintenance area... It's difficult to get large projects to lead/manage.
3> Lots of meaningless reviews, quality assurance activities, etc.

review_title: After lamost 20 years, I still enjoy my work at IBM.
job_title: Software Development Manager in Markham, ON
pros: IBM Software Grouo is active in many areas of technology, so there are always interesting projects to work on.  I have also discovered that it is  very possible to have a great deal of freedom within IBM, provided one can demonstrate the value of what you are doing.
cons: During the Gerstner years, there seemed to be less focus on process, audits, etc.  That, sadly, has been returning lately.  Also, givne the current (jan 2009) economic woes, there is a fair bit of apprehension among employees--however, I suspect that is true of almost all companies and all employees these days 8-(.

review_title: IBM Consulting  isn't for everyone.
pros: It is a large company with lots of opportunity.
cons:
It is a large company with lots of processes and people to navigate. You can easily get stuck in a staffing pool and sitting unbillable - all as a result of business conditions and with no reflection on your individual skill. Nevertheless, they require a high billability - something in the mid-ninties - for you to even be considered for promotion. 

In addition, clients were not always the most educated buyers of consulting services so you had to justify your existance inside and outside the company. 

IBM also has substantial outsourcing capabilities but none of them relate to decks or writing.

review_title: Like it or leave it.
pros: Relative job security - in a tough environment IBM will weather the storm better than others.
cons:
There is little employee representation at IBM, and no Union that can be spoken of.  Performance ratings [PBC] are often used to justify separation and avoid redundancy payments.  

There is a forced distribution on performance ratings across GBS whereby over 60% of staff must come up as "average performer".  As a resuly your objectives [which are forced onto you, not negotiated as such: an email from the MD tells you what to write] are more or less binding depending on what rating the "management team" wants to give you.

review_title: It's not what it used to be
pros:
Brand recognition will get you in the door but our cost base is much too high in China to be taken seriously.

Have some fantastic solutions.

They don't treat their people with respect any longer.

review_title: Lot of opportunities but only on paper unless you can be really assertive
pros: Lot of opportunities, collaboration between technical peers is excellent, availability of learning materials are immense on anything from leadership, management , technology or industries.
cons: Management is arrogant, some technical leaders with hold information and do not share, walls between departments causes movement difficult, information not shared between projects, help is given only if it effect your appraisals, too much impetus on intellectual capital and patents, quantity over quality.

review_title: Pure bodyshop - employees are nothing but commodities.

pros: - work-life balance -- work from home allowed
cons:

-- Raise and bonus are a joke, compared to industry
-- Career progression is bureaucratic and not merit based 

it is a heavily matrixed organization filled with ego-centric mediocre managers who have no competitiveness in them -- IBM is successful not because of skill but because of size. It needs some decent competition to spin the leaderships head.

review_title: Relative ranking is absolutely past its time.
pros:
A diverse set of roles are available for those looking to move within the company.
Significant opportunity to work with other Fortune 500 companies and clients.
cons:
The relative ranking system is now causing solid workers to be flagged as poor performers; someone has to do the grunt work.
Extremely difficult to move between software group brands or to different divisions.

review_title: very nice people, very outgoing, the interview was about 1h and has included a easy technical test .
job_title: Subject Matter Expert (SME)/Technical Mentor in Sofia, Sofia (city)
pros: The company allows me to grow, develop and mostly to have a touch point with the upper management. There is a huge resource of people and money, provided i manage to make my point i regards to a project.
cons: It's not a place to chill, that's for shore. If you want to have someone holding your hand this is the wrong place, IBM i'ts all about efficiency, customer care and pro-activity (personnel) . So if you want to learn, if you want to grow and if you are open minded you'r welcome

review_title: Great Learning Experience, Low Benefit
pros: Working in GBS Indonesia will get you a flexible time, Good work life balance, Great learning experience, and Friendly and Helpful colleagues and boss. On terms of career, you can have a boost of career, depends on how great your contribution and eagerness in work.
cons: Working in GBS Indonesia do not provide great benefit if you start at low / medium level career, a low salary, low mileage on project, very little perks to makes the employee comfy at the office (no espresso machine, no tissue, etc)

review_title: Huge company with some exceptional people, but gets in it's own way.  Poor people management excellent financial mgt.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Deep pockets and technology to properly fund and support interesting projects, great wealth of talented people to draw from, many whom go on to start other companies.  Good social and technical  interaction between employees all over the world = excellent teaming.  Acquisitions have been very well chosen.
cons: Inconsistent management, too much politics and no long term measurement of management decisions.  Acquisitions not well integrated quickly enough, focus on process may unnecessarily scare away good talent - since most of it is trivial.

review_title: Acquisitions instead of skill development for current employees
job_title: Project Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Global company with a tradition of technical excellence (read the con for context).
cons: IBM is bent on meeting a 2015 stock increase commitment at all costs.  There is no avenue for skill development for current employees that wish to move into roles in emerging areas.  Why train someone in analytics or public cloud when you can buy a company and it's people.  If you join the company have a full handle of your careerpath and when you deviate from your goal, move on.  There is no loyalty and the golden years of caring about employees is gone for good.

review_title: Very well organized company.  We were purchased by IBM and integrated slowly and efficiently.
pros: If you like high structure and rules, this is the company for you.  Procedures are well written. Travel sites and reimbursement is easy and done quickly.  If you enjoy a specialized area such as consulting or sales, lots of opportunities.  Using Sametime instead of email is very nice.
cons: If you need more flexibility and growth - IBM usually takes longer to do anything. Resources like software and hardware can take awhile to obtain.  Management normally is not proficient in technical skills but in manager skills.

review_title: Application Developer career at IBM
pros: A wonderful company with employee friendly policies. Mother of computer , it has vast opportunities in different vertical and countries. It does the business pretty much in all fields related to IT, spanning over consultancy, infrastructure,software, services and research.
cons: A great company with lot of bureaucracy , a lot of unnecessary process and documentation became cause of inefficiency. Poor business model encourage sales over software development.  They are becoming inefficient day by day due to burden of its own legacy and inertia against change

review_title: Good company to work with if you want to spend the retirement  life.. Makes people lazy.
pros: Good place to work... Have ample time to spend with family and friends.
cons: No Salary Hike. No basis facilities (ex: Tea and coffee are charged). Manager driven company. Growth is dependent on the line manager. CEO talks and give the big picture of the company, but failed to correct basis thing.

review_title: Advisory Systems Management Integration Professional
job_title: Advisory Systems Management Integration Professional in Greensboro, NC
pros: I've worked for IBM for 13 years.  When I started it was a good place to work, good benefits, good training, but that's changed over the years.  I can't remember the last time I got any real training.  I guess the benefits are still reasonably good compared to what other companies have.
cons: If you're in Strategic Outsourcing, good luck to you, but you have to see what's been happening, as more and more people are laid off.  Like I mentioned above, the training (which was one of the best things about this job) has totally dried up.  So now you have below average pay to go along with no training, and no opportunities to really move up in the company either.

review_title: Vague values and poor execution
pros: Many potential paths for career development are highlighted,  Good high level PR and marketing.    Generally good folks in the trenches.
cons: Zero to no support for any innovation from employees despite plenty of management rhetoric about vitality.  Companies purchased for this are bled dry.   Direction changes quarterly based on poor financial results, latest reorganization, and incessant rise of next "executive resource".  Once dominant sales culture has been replaced by finance and HR.

review_title: Great company to make software
pros: Unimaginable amount of expertise, resources, and career opportunities. The company encourages excellent values on their employees. You can do technology research, technology incubation, and development at any scale. Easy to contain work within office hours.
cons: As you can imagine some bureaucracy comes with it, but it's not as much as you would expect from a company that big. And although it may look like an hard to bend, it's changed and move a lot over the last years. Not that competitive salary.

review_title: Informatica Developer having 4 Yrs of Exp
pros: Working for a Best Place to Work isn’t only going to keep you satisfied, but it can boost your career as well.
cons: In today's hectic business world, people try cramming as much into the work days as possible. When employees are trying to finish up all the tasks on their to-do lists, 40-hour workweeks can easily morph into 45 or 50--and work can begin to impinge on their leisure time. To ease the stress of not having enough free time, some employees look to job sharing-- the process of splitting one full-time job between two people--in order to take back control of their lives and spend it the way they want.

review_title: Patience Required
job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Flexible work environment and good opportunity for those that put forward effort.  Cognitive future embedded on cloud platform- CAMSS - cloud, analytics, mobile, security, social - focus around these core to strategy.
cons: Long hours leads to nonexistent work life balance.  Not industry leading compensation any longer - very focused on cost take out/reduction of work force in North America.

review_title: Good for beginners
pros: Offers a great number of career growth options and it's a decent place to start a career since they accept graduates with no experience. The environment is fairly dynamic and you can feel that people have a desire to do better.
cons: Fairly old technology used in most cases. Work progression can be too slow, rife with nepotism and even examples of managers keeping their talented people behind because they don't want to risk replacing them. Salary disparity can be huge between people doing the same job, salary increases are capped per year and salary is overall not very competitive.

review_title: Good place to work, great people
job_title: Technical Sales Engineer in London, England
pros: Very innovative driven people who know how to get things done.  More software and technology than you know what to do with.  Some of the most interesting things I have ever worked on.
cons: Losing market share and presence.  Startups and smaller more reactive companies getting ahead of some of the software products.  Too much middle management, too much manage by spreadsheet, execs so high up they don't know what is really happening.  Product managers to obsessed with selling internally rather than marketing their products and trying to catch up to the competition

review_title: Downward spiral with no focus on customer
pros: Fair (and declining) benefits, good salary, flexibility of hours.  You are not micromanaged (other than staffing decision)
cons: Benefits rapidly declining (paying more for less insurance, 401K matching diminished and must be there at end of year), multiple layoffs per year, company strategy to realign is purely words and only strategy is to shift work overseas.  No focus on customer satisfaction.  Forcing layoffs for even profitable employees.  Micromanaged staffing decisions.

review_title: Solid place to work

review_title: IBM design is nothing more than lumpy mashed potatoes
job_title: User Experience Designer in Austin, TX
pros: There are many smart people that work here. The designers can really push themselves on challenging domains and products.
cons:
Every business organization is inconsistent on everything. There are many that follow IBM design thinking and others that don’t. Teams struggle to releases any product or any type of software. Which leads to a lot of designers hopping to new teams to find something better. I have seen design teams cut and the project moved to development (great way for a company being “design focus”).
 
I will only speak to what team I was on. The management is all over the place. My team went through three design leads in less than a year and a half. Our Program Director didn’t know how to deal with any of the problems in our business platform/team so they would just move people around never addressing the problem.
 
You could see how overwhelmed and inexperienced some of the design leads were. One in general couldn’t lead the team and placed most of the responsibility on other team members. If you didn’t meet demands we were blamed for failure or even an ultimatum to stay or move teams. When asked what they did they would respond with “going to meetings.” With little to no directions, you scrounged for work. If you didn’t know what you should be doing or asked what you could do you got nothing more than “You should know.”
 
There were no check-ins and the design lead assumed you were taking advantage of them. There are goals and performance system but the lead didn’t effectively use or acknowledge it until it was too late for the designer. Most of the designers left the team for new teams and some tried to stick it out in hope it would get better. Program Director should have intervened but never solved the problem but switched old designers with industry designers (A few months later everyone was moved off and development are performing design).
 
The culture at IBM design can be summed up as everyone's out for themselves and less than teams. It is my observation employees work in secret not sharing their work. If you didn’t have a loud voice or opinions, you were cut down or see as weak. How do you grow at IBM? It’s hard with a culture where you are viewed as weak. Then you are pushed out.

review_title: Great Brand, Terrible Management
job_title: Market Intelligence Professional in Armonk, NY
pros: The Name is huge, and there are lots of smart people who are also decent human beings.
cons:
The brand name is the only reason that I selected some areas of satisfaction in this poll, because IBM will help my career growth when I decide to use the brand name to land something much better outside the company. It's pathetic how they bring in talented people, train them, and then stupidly lose them because compensation is sub-par for the level or work and workload, and management is out of touch and arrogant. Great strategy - spend money to hire and train and then let other companies reap the benefits. It seems like the really good people leave unless they become someone's pet and find a political loophole to career advancement. The good ones who stay probably do it for family reasons due to workplace flexibility, or don't want to take a risk... IBM should be one of the most sought after companies to work for, but it's just a place to build a great resume for 2-5 years and move on for anyone with career ambitions. 

I haven't worked outside of Market Insights, but from what I hear, this is supposed to be one of the best places to work. Maybe it is by IBM standards, but not by what you would expect. There are way too many politics. Management doesn't even take the time to get to know employees or take an active part in developing them. It's all passive. The employee has to initiate everything (career talk, mentorship, and even just basic learning about how to do the job). You only interact with the first line managers even though the executives make the decisions. If you get a few minutes with them, they act like God. It's an outdated style in today's world. It sounds nice to say that employees should manage their own careers, but there's way too much workload and secrecy to cut through. Most of my senior colleagues tell me that if you want to advance, it's more about wasting working time to put on shows and kiss executive ass than about the quality of the work. Doesn't sound like a lot of fun when you can just leverage the name for 50-100% higher salary and a better title... The thing is that management could avoid that by just respecting and fairly compensating employees when they have the chance, but that makes too much sense.

review_title: IBM - Big Blue - Hunting For Bargain Basement Deals
pros:
Very flexible in working remotely from home for many positions - just be aware that that sooner or later your job / position will be off-shored to a cheaper 3rd world country, no matter how great of performer you are or how dedicated you might be.

This is a good company for any fresh-out-of-school job hunter that wants to gain some standard 21st corporate world experience.  The pay is not bad for the fresh-out-of-school job hunter. For more experienced workers however, IBM is very limited. Executive management's not-so-secret agenda is to layoff as many "high priced" USA-based employees (and in other developed countries) and off-shore everything possible to the 3rd world. Any gaps are theoretically back-filled with the "layoffees" as contractors, assuming they can't find work elsewhere.
cons:
IBM is not a place where job hunters should apply if they are seeking long term employment.or stabilitry.  One day an IBM employee may come into work as he/she has done for the past 20+ years and be taken into the manager's office to be told their position is being Resource Actioned (IBM does  not like to use the words "Laid Off").  The soon to be EX Employee will then be required to stick around for the next 30 days.  This 30 dats period is so the soon to be EX Employee will have tyhe privilage to train their  India Replacement staff member.  Once the 30 days is past and the training is complete the EX Employee will no longer be needed and will be thrown out like yesterday's garbage.

You'll have lots of exposure to different technologies at IBM. Unfortunately, a lot of what's forced on you is either proprietary, obscure, or rapidly vanishing outside the world of IBM (think Lotus Word Pro, Lotus Notes, Domino, etc). Many US-based jobs at IBM are "tenuous", so the workplace feels a lot like dining under the Sword of Damocles. Since your co-workers know that the end could come at any moment, and their survival depends upon how well they rank compared to you, the result is reduced information flow/share, cooperation, participation, and general workplace camaraderie among your co-workers. 

On the subject of "how you rank", the PBC system (performance reviews) at IBM is a TOTAL FARCE. It's basically a random system of ranking by the managers. Worse yet, you usually already have a performance number assigned before the evaluations ever begin -- based on who the manager's favorite employees are, how many people in the dept the execs said will need to be laid off in the next year, etc.

review_title: Not what it used to be.
pros: Looks good on a resume.  Often get to work on new technologies.  There are still many, many great folks there.
cons:
Full disclosure:  I was laid off.  However, I am not a bitter and angry ex-IBMer - I was elated to get my layoff package (very reasonable) and  found a new, much better paying job before my severance ran out.  IBM was very good to me for many, many years (and my tenure started long after the golden years before the early 1990's) and I'm too young to have been personally affected by the pension shenanigans. My review comes from working in the Server group.

It is no secret that IBM's "strategy" has been to reduce it's US workforce.  They're achieving this by two methods:  small but continuous layoffs spread throughout the company and by making it more unpleasant to work there to encourage attrition. The unpleasantness ranges from big things (most people haven't had a raise in years) to the petty (no coffee, no soap in the kitchens, etc.).  Meanwhile, the senior executives are making millions upon millions  Consequently morale throughout the entire company is extremely poor.

Training?  Only if it's free and local (no travel expenses).
Raises?  Small and non-existent.  IBM redefined their salary ranges a few years ago.  We used to 
   hear you've got lots of growth left in your salary range.  Now you hear, "well, you're near the 
    mid-point of your range, so you're paid what you should be paid.  It's like jumping halfway to a 
    wall - you'll never reach it.
Salaries?  When I worked there, I thought it wasn't bad, but three of us have left my team in the 
   past two years and we've each received pay increases at our new companies in excess of 30% 
   and that's been in this terrible economy.
Working Conditions?  Varies widely throughout the company depending on your local mgmt and 
    location.  It was generally pretty good where I was in the Pacific NW.
Career?  At the big sites, there's plenty of places to transfer or try new jobs.  Smaller remote 
   sites are more limited.  And there's no way IBM's paying for anybody's relocation.  
Promotions?  Still possible if you're on the right projects or working with the right customers.  Pay 
   raises are minimal with a promotion, but at least the halfway point in your salary range is a little 
   further away after a promotion.

IBM's always been beauracratic, but local management always had flexibility to take care of their people.  That's gone now, First and Second line managers are now probably the worst jobs in IBM.  They're reduced to just implementing the new and often petty people policies dreamed up by the execs.

review_title: If you are in a good group or active project it's a great place to be. Otherwise, it's a grind.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Pleasanton, CA
pros:
-- IBM is committed to making alternative work situations available to employees: work at home, work in the nearest office, etc. When your company is worldwide, this makes sense.
-- I work with some very intelligent people who are genuinely interested in what they do.
-- Depending on your product/project, you get to work on what interests you (within reason, of course). I'm going to work on some new technology that I've been wanting to work on for a while now.
-- My pay is better than any other place I have worked.
-- They take the annual review process very seriously, from the writing of goals to regular review of your progress towards your goals. I haven't been here long enough to know what the annual review itself is like.
-- The people I have direct contact with are very helpful and a pleasure to be around every day. People have a lot of respect for their coworkers and immediate management, but there seems to be a general contempt for the bigger company and its processes and policies, however.
cons:
-- This is an enormous company. There's a lot of stuff going on, and it's very easy to tune out the rest of your division. As a result, personal and career growth tools and advice are about as generic and non-specific as possible, and therefore not all that useful.
-- Size makes finding useful information on the company intranet almost impossible. Pages are frequently out of date, and you seem to be redirected to 2-3 other pages before you find anything of use.
-- No two groups seem to use the same technology for source control, access management, requirements management, or just about anything else.
-- For some, it's such a good place to work that it's impossible for anyone else to advance into a technical leadership role, so you end up leaving or creating something new and esoteric to make your mark, which makes it even harder for someone new to figure out what's going on.
-- Benefits (primarily health care) are not as good as other places I've worked.
-- Can be very hard to figure out who your customer really is, or who is using what you work on.

Bottom line:

It's almost impossible to describe the 'good and bad of IBM', because it's such a huge company. IBM has acquired so many other companies in the past few years that you can't really describe the culture of IBM anymore. There are a few unifying pieces, like benefits and the review process, but if you want to work at IBM you will want to talk to a lot of people during your interview to find out more about the specific site you want to work at.

review_title: IBM is a great place to work.
GTS: Horrific culture. Salary discrepancies. Just don't work there.
job_title: Project Manager/Account Manager in London, England
pros:
Lots of online learning available on "Your Learning". Unlimited opportunity to work with multi-cultural teams (virtually, not physically). If you start as a Graduate, the salary is good to begin with. Lots of Women in IT events and lots of LGBT+ support/community. 
Ability to manage own time is very good - very autonomous IF you get the right project/manager.
cons:
Shocking culture that comes down from the top. Their main focus is on short-term financial success without considering the impact on their workforce or the client. They say "client comes first" but I have never seen IBM encourage this behaviour internally, what they really mean is "bring in the money first, then Client comes second". Financial gain is so important to them that it encouraged to bend accounting rules as much as possible, even if it means a loss in the future - as long as they can get the gain now. 
Senior management bark down the phone at people and you're made to feel guilty if you can't attend certain calls (on Saturdays...). 
Employees don't take responsibility for their actions. This is not out of not-wanting to be responsible and own actions, it is out of fear of the repocussions should something go wrong.
There is absolutely no movement for progression or promotion (on GTS side, anyway). Yes, it's a good starting salary for a Graduate, however by the end of the 2yr Grad scheme you will be earning less than the market value compared to your non-IBM peers - they say they compare your salary to a PMR aka Market Value, yet this PMR hasn't been updated in years and is different for men vs women. 
Immediate-management don't have the time to actually support their team in career development, as they have a full-time job to do and being a people manager is just an additional task on the side. 
Finally, they're off-shoring everything. They have a 60/20/20 vision aka 60% resource far-shore (India), 20% near-shore (Slovakia/Bratislava) and 20% on-shore (UK). Not only do remote colleagues not have the skills to step-into the shoes of those they are replacing in the UK (and by replacement I mean made-redundant), but the cultures don't support each other. In the UK, employees work long-hours until the job is done. In India, colleagues don't know how to think outside of a process or list of instructions for e.g. if something goes wrong and the way around it isn't on the process list then they will just stop and not do anything, they won't even come back and tell you it's not working. You will be constantly chasing them. In east-Europe, if it's 17.01 they go home. So be prepared to have to work double hard to cater for the slack elsewhere. In addition, the IMI service in India is fairly new, about 3yrs old. This means that the colleague skills are way below-par and still being trained. About 70% of my stress was caused by IMI's inability to complete a job. 
If you want to work for a company that is all about the business and dollar signs, IBM is for you. If you want a great culture, progression and support - find somewhere else.
p.s. There's no free tea/coffee - you even have to pay 25p for hot water. Just to show you how low these guys go to save a buck...

pros: You are surrounded by the smartest people in the world.  This is the first job I had where I didn't feel like I was working with a bunch of idiots.  It was fun to work on developing the latest and greatest technology.
cons:
Everyone is always worried about the next RA.
1st line managers hands are tied.
Executive leadership is very short sighted.

review_title: Buen ambiente de trabajo, pero bajas prestaciones
pros: In my experience, the corporate policy of ethics is followed and beneficial in many aspects to employees. A lot of experienced coworkers are very helpful, and there is usually no problem getting help from other IBM sites. As a software engineer which is not very often in contact with clients, I'm not required to wear formal clothing, which is actually great.
cons: Salaries are not updated in line with inflation, and raises need an outstanding PBC (annual evaluation) which is very difficult since they're mostly limited to a percentage by policy.

review_title: 23 + years, 2 tours of Duty
job_title: Procurement Category Manager in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Great Co-workers, very talented. Work from home is encourages, most of the time.
cons: Benefits and pay sucks, constant layoffs. I started in 1984, and it was the best place to work, now one of the worst. Morale is horrible, and management does not care. no chance of upward mobility, Clueless management, except for a 1st level once in a while. Right now you have entry level kids, and grey beards with 20++++ years. When they leave there will be no skills or expertise left. IBM can't fulfill commitments now with lack of talent.

review_title: IBM Review
pros: IBM is a great place to work:  Challenging work, smart people, good compensation packages.  Also, management requires constant coursework and training.
cons: IBM is a bit hampered by its size.  Because it is so large, IBM operates in a bureaucratic manner to maintain operational effectiveness.  Ironically, this operational efficacy of IBM's makes it tougher to make quick decisions.  Decisions are always slow in coming but extremely sound once made.

review_title: Cheat with commissions
pros:
The Pros are that in countries IBM is one of the best companies to work for.
Its just the Dublin sales center that have some problems to keep the best sales reps
cons:
In Dublin sales center, they are known to cheat with sellers commissions.
If you are a super sales rep... they have processes in place to reduce the commissions. 

Absolutely no chance for the best sellers to become managers as their managers loose to much revenue (= commissions for the managers). 
These cons are valid for the Dublin Sales center. IBM in countries are GREAT!

review_title: Applications Developer
pros: Great opportunities to travel while on projects. Meeting awesome co-workers. Able to get vacation time even if you started with the company in the middle of the year
cons: They are not completely honest about the job description while in the interview or with the posting online. You have to be on a project. If not you are at risk of being fired within a few months. Even if there are no project in your service line.

review_title: Great job out of college
job_title: Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros: If you are coming out of college, don't know what you want to do, and are looking to learn about a number of different businesses and industries, IBM is a fantastic place to work.
cons: If you don't want to travel, stay away.  You'll be on the road almost every week.  But for some, that might be great!  Can't beat the miles!

review_title: Software Developer
pros:
Lots of smart people that are willing to help you learn. 
Everyone is very helpful. 
Ability to work on big important projects that can have a huge impact on the World.
The people around you want to see you succeed and want to help.
cons:
You can get lost in such a big company. It's hard to not feel like a small person in a large machine.
Not much leadership from management, but there are others around that can help teach you the in's and out's on the company.

review_title: Senior consultant straight out of MBA
pros: Great place to begin a career; learn business and technical skills and gain experience working directly with clients; everybody knows IBM so great name recognition for those looking to move on
cons: Size of the organization and the fact that junior consultants spend most of their time onsite with clients makes it difficult to get noticed within IBM; where unproven junior consultants end up is largely luck of the draw

review_title: Retail Industry Consultant
job_title: Retail Industry Consultant in London, England
pros: Flexible working from home opportunities and great scope to work internationally from a very early stage in your career. Good access to training during the graduate scheme.
cons: Poor bonus culture and canteen is not well subsidised (charges money for hot water)! It's also very difficult to change areas within the business once you have been placed somewhere which means you can feel a little pigeon holed early on in your career.

review_title: Good flexibility, limited visibility
pros:
amazing work from home opportunities
very women friendly
good learning - depends upon the project you are in
very good for freshers or for highly experienced and family people who want work life balance
cons:
Everything depends upon the manager, there is very limited visibility of individual since you tend to get lost in the crowd. 
Hikes are very less or no hikes. 
They are too lazy to speed up the processes and will keep you waiting for small organizational things.

review_title: Mixed Thoughts
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Most of my time was a good experience (even without having been there in the "good old days" of high bonuses and respect for the employee as part of their values).  Many positions offered flexibility to work from home.
cons: The "threat" of layoff always loomed which didn't help morale for those that made the skew each year.  News about the company was often received on the local news (which turned out to be true), only later to be briefly communicated by management. Focus at EOQ set unrealistic precedent for employees to perform miracles with little work/life balance.

review_title: Public Sector Consulting by Degrees
pros:
- Good starting base pay
- Consulting by degrees program training
- Fast promotion to senior consultant
cons:
- Can get pigeonholed easily
- Public sector projects are year long commitments and therefore you do not have a true consulting experience
- Lack of project diversity
- Easier to quit IBM and get rehired than to move to another department 
- Hard to differentiate or shine when you're on a government contract

review_title: Senior IT Specialist
job_title: IT Specialist/Technical Sales in Boston, MA
pros: Good people to work with.  Most of the people at IBM really do try to do the right thing for their customers.  The amount of talent is ofter amazing.
cons: Too large, hard to get the right things done.  Reluctant to change.  Although there is a lot of talent to work with the internal processes make it hard to get things done.

review_title: Former software engineer
pros:
Wide breadth of resources means you can almost always find an answer to a question from someone
Large technical community and opportunities to learn on the job
A lot of opportunity to move within the company and be exposed to wide range of technology
cons:
Command and control management style
Who you know matters more than what you know
Aggressively move jobs overseas
Quarter to quarter pivoting in direction and deciding what's important

review_title: Confusing direction
pros:
Flexible working environment

Trust for the individual
cons:
In the last few years its my belief IBM has lost itself - Each year brings another restructure and another way of doing things which takes about 10 month to partially implement before the following year hits with another new direction!

Lots of  demotivated and confused staff currently as new approaches are unclear with uncertainty around implementation

Evidence of bullying tactics creeping in as profit and revenue achievements are not growing as expected

review_title: Not what it once was...
job_title: Sales Management Advisor in Tampa, FL
pros: Can work from home (although that is ending for most people).
cons: Corporate management cares only with enriching themselves.  Revenue shrinking continually for the past 5 years.  Massive layoffs are a regular thing now.  Experienced, talented employees are no longer valued and are being replaced with younger, cheaper (and less talented) people at an alarming rate.  CEO talks about hiring 25,000 people in the US, but MANY more than that are being laid off.  Corporate management is dishonest about the overall state of the company.  Morale is terrible.  No pay raises for the past 5+ years.  No promotion opportunities.

review_title: Great potential....but
pros: A very large portfolio of software products and the potential to provide an end to end platform to help companies know and sell to their customers.
cons: A culture that sells speeds and feeds/features and benefits as opposed to providing solutions. A company focusing on short-term gains to the exclusion of ensuring its future.

review_title: IBM Solutions Delivery (ISD)
job_title: Applications Developer/Configuration Management in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: Working in IBM is a dream come true for me since I started my Mainframe Career on 2006. IBM is a place full of technical resources including its people. Also IBM is an awesome workplace since some accounts especially the "Internal Accounts" having the option for WFH (Work-From-Home). Benefits-wise I was able to received good benefits including healthcare for the whole family.
cons: It would be then the scarcity for Mainframe projects.  There are very good people whose skillset is under Mainframe are now moving out because of it.

review_title: System Administrator
pros:
- Good work balance
- Nice Health Plan
- Excellent learning initiatives (Pluralsight, O'Reilly Safari Books, etc.)
cons:
- Work with really-old-technologies.
- Things move slowly.
- In many projects, it's hard to accept innovation and new tools.
- State of the art of Bureaucracy

review_title: Excellent opportunities
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Bethesda, MD
pros: Verizon sold their cloud/hosting business to IBM in Sep/2017 and I was among those who transitioned to IBM. From the beginning, I noticed how IBM offers a more organized environment, with excellent opportunities to improve and expand our careers, with clear learning paths and multiple resources.
cons: Health insurance options seem to be designed for singles, who get free health insurance. Married individuals with kids pay expensive insurance to have spouses and kids covered. Compared to what I used to have at Verizon, IBM health care plans offer less and charge way more.

review_title: Lost in their transformation effort
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good ethics. Provide employees the freedom to take  new initiatives. Lot of lateral move options to gain a wide range of experience.
cons: Disconnected and at times dysfunctional communication across the layers and layers of hierarchy. Extremely difficult to move the needle on outcomes due to the complexity of the organization and processes. Letting people go is a continuous process in IBM  which creates a permanent state of flux resulting in lackluster performance.

review_title: IBM-Review
pros: As a women I really feel IBM is the only best to be worked. Work environment is so flexible. IBM provides each & every info related to  its new product and makes sure all employees go thru those training and get certified.IBM also includes many other non work activities too which gives a good relief to employee. It provides work from home option based on emergency but that will very kneely monitored.
cons: As all other MNC's IBM also gives less yearly hike for employees. Getting promotion is also very difficult.

review_title: Operations team, GTS needs to be regulated, huge differences in salaries
pros: Unlimited sick leaves, good for ladies who have because at times they need WFH... I totally appreciate it

Contractor can have any qualifications in GTS, they might have repeaters, failures, and can w9rk as bots for u.
Higher managements should be reviewed as there are so many parasites in company which can be kicked of immediately... They are not at all in office, if they will be in office, they just come for free coffee and newspapers.

review_title: Cares most about its bottom line, customers and employees are after-thoughts
job_title: Accelerated Value Leader in Markham, ON
pros:
- Flexibility, e.g. flexible hours, work from home, personal days
- Working with the smartest people you’d meet
- Great internal support
- IBM and its tech are respected by customers

- Salary was not competitive relative to the market; bonuses were rare and salaries were rare adjusted to match inflation
- Some parts of the company were cut to the bone and worse
